document.title: [Personal Note] Why do we have all these kinds of update?

para.p:
footnote
\addbibresourcerefs.bib
\SetCommentStymycommfont

In this paper \parencitemadjiheurem2021expected, the authors motivate their new type of updates with this line of reasoning. The well-known TD-update only update value of the immediately preceding states (given if the reward is not zero). The eligibility trace improves upon this by making the update propagating back multiple states along the observed trajectory. Then they proposed that we can even make a step further by not only updating all states along observed trajectory but also all “plausible” counterfactual trajectories.

Although the reasoning is nicely motivated, I am not convinced and want to know why or how do we have all these kinds of updating. There should be a principle that they are all based on which the author seemingly assume all audience are aware of. I think the origin problem starts with the TD-update. Let’s trace back from it.

While the ultimate goal of using RL might be abstract and unqualitative, one must explicitly provide some objective so that we can have a certain of how good/bad are we doing. One of the such common goal is discounted cumulative reward. Be aware of that there are others goal, the reason of choosing this is out of scope for now. It is defined as

Math.text: G _ pi = E * delimited-[]@(((sum ^ infinity) _ (t = 0))@(gamma ^ t * r _ t))

para.p: where the expectation is token over all available random variables. So we want to maximize a sum of all rewards, including the immediate reward with higher weight and future rewards with less significant weightings, and taking its average over multiple run.

The goal does not concern with variance, which means it might output a good policy in terms of average but might be very very unstable, e.g., getting a very high
G
on a particular run, and moderate
G
for other
99
runs.

We use
S i
as a random variable of state at time step
t
,
s i
as a particular state in a set of states
=
S ,
| S |
N
. Similar,
A i
is used as a random variable of action at time step
i
,
a i
as a particular action in a set of actions
=
A ,
| A |
M
;
:
⁢ r
(
S i
,
A i
)
→
× S A
R
as a reward received at time step
i
;

A way to decompose this
G
is

Math.text: G _ pi = E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 0, A _ 0) + gamma * r * open-interval@(S _ 1, A _ 1) + gamma ^ 2 * r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ t * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + ldots)
G _ pi

absent = E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 0, A _ 0) + gamma * r * open-interval@(S _ 1, A _ 1) + gamma ^ 2 * r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ t * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + ldots)

absent = E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 0, A _ 0) + gamma * (underbrace@(E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 1, A _ 1) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + ldots))) _ [this term is still a RV])

XMText.text: this term is still a RV

Math.text: absent = E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 0, A _ 0) + gamma * (underbrace@(E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 1, A _ 1) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + ldots))) _ [this term is still a RV])

XMText.text: this term is still a RV

Math.text: absent = E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 0, A _ 0) + gamma * V * S _ 1)
absent = E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 0, A _ 0) + gamma * V * S _ 1)

para.p: where we define something called value function as follow.

A value function of a policy is a real-value function,
:
V π
→ S R
, and is defined as

Math.text: V _ pi * (S _ 1 = s) assign E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(s, A _ 1) + gamma * r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + conditional@(ldots, S _ 1) = s)

para.p:
where
S 1
is the state input,
S 2
,
S 3
, …
are next states relatively to
S 1
(index
1
does not mean anything specific here, just indicate a relative temporal index).

The conditioning
=
S 1
s
is necessary since all remaining RVs
A 1
,
S 2
,
A 2
, …
depend on that information. To make it clear, take a look at a quantity without that condition

Math.text: E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(s, A _ 1) + gamma * r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + ldots)

para.p:
Since it needs to be deterministic, the expectation is taking over
A 1
, which makes no sense since there is no
⁢ P
(
A 1
)
, we only have
⁢ P
(
|
A 1
S 1
)
. Similarly, the expectation is taking over
∼
S 2
⁢ P
(
S 2
)
. This is again wrong since doing this takes no account for a piece of observation that previous state is
=
S 1
s
. This can go on …

Value function at a state
s
, i.e.,
⁢
V π
(
=
S 1
s
)
is a deterministic quantity.

Value function is time invariant, i.e.,
=
⁢
V π
(
=
S t
s
)
⁢
V π
(
=
S k
s
)
for any
≥
t , k
0
.

Since it is time invariant, we will use
⁢
V π
(
S 1
)
as convention.
Value function of a state can be described by value function of other states.

Math.text: V _ pi * (S _ 1 = s) = E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(s, A _ 1) + gamma * r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + conditional@(ldots, S _ 1) = s)
V _ pi * (S _ 1 = s)
absent = E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(s, A _ 1) + gamma * r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + conditional@(ldots, S _ 1) = s)

absent = list@(E _ A _ 1 * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(s, A _ 1) + conditional@(gamma * E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + ldots), S _ 1) = s), [(splitting RVs)])

absent = list@(E _ A _ 1 * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(s, A _ 1) + conditional@(gamma * E * delimited-[]@(r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + ldots), S _ 1) = s), [(splitting RVs)])

absent = (sum _ (i = 1))@([Pr] * (A _ 1 = conditional@(a _ i, S _ 1) = s) * (r * open-interval@(s, a _ i) + gamma * E * delimited-[]@(formulae@(r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + conditional@(ldots, S _ 1) = s, A _ 1 = a _ i))))

absent = (sum _ (i = 1))@([Pr] * (A _ 1 = conditional@(a _ i, S _ 1) = s) * (r * open-interval@(s, a _ i) + gamma * E * delimited-[]@(formulae@(r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 1) * r * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + conditional@(ldots, S _ 1) = s, A _ 1 = a _ i))))

para.p: The last term is

Math.text: E * delimited-[]@(formulae@(r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + gamma * r * open-interval@(S _ 3, A _ 3) + conditional@(ldots, S _ 1) = s, A _ 1 = a _ i))
E * delimited-[]@(formulae@(r * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + gamma * r * open-interval@(S _ 3, A _ 3) + conditional@(ldots, S _ 1) = s, A _ 1 = a _ i))

para.p: Combine those,
With deterministic policy, the outer sum reduces to a single quantity,
For deterministic policy,
We can describe this more compactly using matrix/vector notation. Define the following quantities

Math.text: V = (list@(V _ pi * (S _ 1 = s _ 1), V _ pi * (S _ 1 = s _ 2), ldots, V _ pi * (S _ 1 = s _ (absolute-value@(S))))) ^ top element-of R ^ N
V = (list@(V _ pi * (S _ 1 = s _ 1), V _ pi * (S _ 1 = s _ 2), ldots, V _ pi * (S _ 1 = s _ (absolute-value@(S))))) ^ top element-of R ^ N
P = matrix@(Array[[[Pr(S2=s1|S1=s1,A1=π(s1))], ldots, [Pr(S2=sN∣S1=s1,A1=π(s1))]], [vdots, vdots, vdots], [[Pr(S2=s1|S1=sN,A1=π(sN))], ldots, [Pr(S2=sN|S1=sN,A1=π(sN))]]]) element-of R ^ (N * M * N)
P = matrix@(Array[[[Pr(S2=s1|S1=s1,A1=π(s1))], ldots, [Pr(S2=sN∣S1=s1,A1=π(s1))]], [vdots, vdots, vdots], [[Pr(S2=s1|S1=sN,A1=π(sN))], ldots, [Pr(S2=sN|S1=sN,A1=π(sN))]]]) element-of R ^ (N * M * N)
R = (list@(r * open-interval@(s _ 1, pi * s _ 1), r * open-interval@(s _ 2, pi * s _ 2), ldots, r * open-interval@(s _ N, pi * s _ N))) ^ top element-of R ^ N
R = (list@(r * open-interval@(s _ 1, pi * s _ 1), r * open-interval@(s _ 2, pi * s _ 2), ldots, r * open-interval@(s _ N, pi * s _ N))) ^ top element-of R ^ N

para.p: Then, Block can be expressed compactly as

Math.text: V = R + P * V

p.text: well, it takes forever to reach the contraction operator :(

para.p:
A action-value function of a policy
π
is a real-value function
:
⁢
Q π
( s , a )
→
× S A
R
defined as

Math.text: Q _ pi * formulae@(S _ 1 = s, A _ 1 = a) = limit-from@(r * open-interval@(s, a), +)

para.p:
We have partitioned
G π
into a so-called immediate reward
⁢
r 0
(
S 0
,
A 0
)
and a future reward
⁢ γ V
(
S 1
)
. We can actually do a further step that we decompose
⁢ V
(
S 1

Math.text: V _ pi * S _ 1 = E * delimited-[]@(r _ 1 * open-interval@(S _ 1, A _ 1) + gamma * E * delimited-[]@(r _ 2 * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 2) * r _ t * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + ldots))
V _ pi * S _ 1

absent = E * delimited-[]@(r _ 1 * open-interval@(S _ 1, A _ 1) + gamma * E * delimited-[]@(r _ 2 * open-interval@(S _ 2, A _ 2) + ldots + gamma ^ (t - 2) * r _ t * open-interval@(S _ t, A _ t) + ldots))
absent = E * delimited-[]@(r _ 1 * open-interval@(S _ 1, A _ 1) + gamma * V * S _ 2)
absent = E * delimited-[]@(r _ 1 * open-interval@(S _ 1, A _ 1) + gamma * V * S _ 2)
absent = sum _ (i = 1)
absent = sum _ (i = 1)

Now after we are clear about objective, and getting some insight, let’s talk about method. Define an operator
T
that receives an array
∈ V
R
| S |
, it will output another vector with the same dimension. Vector
V
is defined as

Math.text: V = list@(V * s _ 1, V * s _ 2, ldots, V * s _ n)

para.p:
that is the
i
th element is value of function
V
evaluating at state
s i
. Be aware that
V
is a function defined in (). Confusingly, definition of function
V
involves time, while this vector
V
does not.
